item.title: Yoshi Mario Galaxy Popcorn Bucket Looks Like He Ate A Crazy Edible
item.content:encoded:
The Super Mario Galaxy Movie is coming out in April, and naturally it‚Äôs getting novelty popcorn buckets like every other movie in theaters these days. It looks like Nintendo and Illumination are leaning hard into Yoshi for marketing for the animated sequel, so they‚Äôre making a popcorn bucket of the egg-pooping dinosaur for folks to buy. And my guy looks like he is zooted out of his goddamn mind.

Images of the popcorn bucket started circulating today ahead of any official announcement. You can see Yoshi holding one of his trademark eggs, but he also is giving the kind of thousand-yard stare usually reserved for people who ate an entire bowl of brownies without realizing they‚Äôre loaded with pot. He‚Äôs staring into the Super Mario Galaxy and holding onto that egg like it‚Äôs grounding him to reality. It‚Äôs currently rumored that this container will be available at AMC, Cinemark, and Regal theaters, but we‚Äôre still waiting on an official announcement.

None of the angles we‚Äôve seen thus far make it clear where the popcorn is supposed to go, but novelty popcorn buckets have long stopped caring about function in favor of form. Just look at all the nonsense they put out for Wicked: For Good.

The Super Mario Galaxy Movie is coming to theaters on April 1, and Illumination says that all the animation for the film is complete. We still don‚Äôt know who‚Äôs voicing Yoshi in the sequel, but he sounds pretty much as cute as you‚Äôd expect him to in the trailers. item.title: Call Of Duty Devs Know Safeguard Has Problems And Are Looking Into It
item.content:encoded:
Over a decade ago, Call of Duty: Black Ops III introduced a new multiplayer game mode to the franchise: Safeguard. This team-based mode had players pushing and defending a walking robot from another team tasked with stopping it. It was very good. But the mode‚Äôs last appearance in a main game was in 2018. So I was over the moon to see the mode return as part of Black Ops 7‚Äòs second season. And while I have some issues with it, Safeguard is still a lot of fun in 2026.

Booting up Safeguard in the new season of COD: BLOPS7 was like returning to an old friend‚Äôs house after years away to hang out. Something I‚Äôve always appreciated about the mode was how it gave the defense a way to fight back that wasn‚Äôt just ‚ÄúKill the other team.‚Äù You can instead focus your damage on the robot, and if you do enough, it will stop moving and have to reboot. This gives less skilled players a way to help without having to hunt down highly skilled COD pros each match. It also leads to an interesting dynamic where a defending team can over-focus on taking out the bot and let the attackers flank them and wipe them out. But focus too much on the attackers, and the bot will walk its way into the checkpoint, and you‚Äôll lose before you realize it.

This time around, the robot you are defending is a four-legged Boston Dynamics-like mechanical dog. The bots were previously bipedal humanoids, which was fine, but I‚Äôm far more into guarding a robo dog than a random mechanical man. But it felt to me as if this robot dog might be moving faster than the past bots had in Safeguard. So I talked to the devs behind the mode, and they confirmed that, no, the bot is moving at a ‚Äúpace consistent with previous‚Äù versions of Safeguard.

However, ‚ÄúBO7‚Äôs tighter map layouts, updated pathing, and the new animation set can make its movement feel faster, even though the underlying speed hasn‚Äôt changed much,‚Äù said a Treyarch spokesperson. They also confirmed they are looking at data to decide if the bot should move a bit slower.

Another issue with the current version of Safeguard in Black Ops 7 is that you can sometimes win, but still lose. Basically, the game mode is built around how fast you get the bot to the checkpoint. Each team gets a shot at pulling this off. If the first team does it in let‚Äôs say two minutes, then the other team goes, and if they get the bot there in two minutes and three seconds, they‚Äôll lose despite the bot making it to the checkpoint. This feels bad, and Treyarch tells me they are looking into this.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre evaluating options to end the second round early in situations where the attacking team hasn‚Äôt pushed the Robot far enough in time,‚Äù Treyarch told Kotaku. ‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre looking at this alongside the broader UI improvements already in progress. Our goal is to make the rules and win conditions as clear and intuitive as possible for all players.‚Äù The team is also open to bringing back overtime, which isn‚Äôt included in Safeguard right now.

Besides those issues, and an odd bug that let people knock the bot out with a combat axe that has already been patched, I‚Äôve really enjoyed playing Safeguard again. I think it‚Äôs a great example of how Call of Duty‚Äòs gunplay can be incredibly successful in modes that aren‚Äôt simply about killing each other.

I hope the mode sticks around past season two and, like Kill Confirmed and other fan favorites, return in future Call of Duty games. You don‚Äôt even have to have a robot for this mode to work. If the next Call of Duty isn‚Äôt set in the future but instead WW2 or something, fine, use a jeep. That would still let me enjoy this mode with my friends, even those who aren‚Äôt great at FPS games.

item.title: Gamepad Controls Elden Ring Streamer IRL Using A Wild Balance Hack
item.content:encoded:
Cool stuff is always coming out of the alternative controller community. From rhythm games where you wiggle around on a real skateboard to games where you smack a giant stuffed animal cat butt, the world of weird controllers is awesome and underrated. Luckily, a brand new type of alt control is getting some well-deserved love.

Streamer Perri Karyal is known for making alt controls that allow her to play games using her brain‚Äîbut what if it were the other way around? What if a game could control a player?

On Thursday, Karyal posted a video showing off exactly that. Using a process called galvanic vestibular stimulation (GVS), which basically sends signals to the part of your ear canal that‚Äôs responsible for your sense of balance, Karyal was able to hook up her own body to a controller. 

I can control your balance

I made a device that sends DC current through my head to stimulate my vestibular nerve (called galvanic vestibular stimulation or GVS) and, in doing so, can make me feel completely destabilised. By changing the direction of the current, it can make me‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/XNH0EtRow6

‚Äî Perri (@perrikaryal) February 12, 2026

‚ÄúBy changing the direction of the current, it can make me fall in that direction,‚Äù she explains. The video shows Karyal running in a straight line ‚Äî until a person shifts a joystick to the left, which causes her to veer to the left, too. 

Karyal proceeded to use the tech to simulate G forces while playing Ubisoft‚Äôs 2020 racing game Trackmania. In the video, she sways from side to side in tandem with her digital car, to dizzying effect. She also reports seeing ‚Äúflashing lights,‚Äù which doesn‚Äôt sound too good. The official Trackmania Esports account took notice of Karyal‚Äôs experiment, calling it ‚Äúawesome.‚Äù

The technology that makes this possible is actually quite old. In an NBC article from 2005, journalist Yuri Kageyama tries out GVS: ‚ÄúI found the experience unnerving and exhausting: I sought to step straight ahead but kept careening from side to side. Those alternating currents literally threw me off.‚Äù

Perri Karyal stresses not to replicate this experiment at home, as GVS isn‚Äôt very well-researched and can cause adverse effects. It‚Äôs very cool to watch someone else do it, though!

item.title: The Metal Gear Solid Master Collection Finally Runs At 60FPS On Switch 2
item.content:encoded:
Metal Gear Solid 4 won‚Äôt be out until later this year, but Konami isn‚Äôt letting its last anthology of older Metal Gear Solid games languish in the meantime. The Metal Gear Solid Master Collection Vol. 1 just got its final big update and it adds improved HD resolutions for some of the games, as well as a performance upgrade to finally let the more demanding games run at 60fps on Switch 2.

The big improvements are coming to Metal Gear Solid 1 and Snake Eater. As shown off in this week‚Äôs PlayStation State of Play, they have expanded resolution settings. You can now play with ‚Äúoriginal,‚Äù ‚Äúhigh,‚Äù or ‚Äúmax‚Äù resolution, though at least for the original Metal Gear there are reports that the improved HD textures lead to some weird jaggies on the screen.

The new patch also makes it possible to finally swap the confirm and cancel buttons in the settings menu, and adds key binding options for mouse and keyboard on PC. On Metal Gear Solid 3, meanwhile, the texture pack apparently has a massive 60GB install size for the new upscaled resolutions, letting you boost the game to a bastard version of 4K.

But the most important takeaway from the update is what it does for the game on Nintendo‚Äôs platform. While the Switch 1 version is what it is (not great!), the Switch 2 version can now reportedly run Metal Gear Solid 2 and Snake Eater at roughly 60fps instead of being locked at 30fps. The upgrade adds a range of new options for customizing the internal resolution and upscaling outputs across the main game and the cinematics, letting fans find what they feel is the optimal compromise between the original look and feel of these games and modern expectations for crisp and smooth performance.

The original release of the the Metal Gear Solid Master Collection Vol. 1 was fairly disappointing given the stature and significance of the games involved. But Konami has slowly made things right over the course of two years and several updates. The Switch 2 upgrade is the final make-good and brings performance in-line with the other console versions on PS5 and Xbox Series X/S. Now every time it goes on sale on Switch I don‚Äôt have to shy away from recommending it to people, including right now. It‚Äôs currently 30 percent off on all platforms.
